docs.lead_paragraph: IF I had been paying more attention, I might have noticed the plaque outside the room that the obstetrician was ushering us into: Patient Education. And had I noticed, I almost surely would have been alarmed. I was 20 weeks pregnant with my first child and had just had a ''routine'' ultrasound examination. What did I need to be educated about? But I did not notice, and I was not anxious or on guard. I had enjoyed the sonogram. Expectant parents do. It is a bonding opportunity. It is baby's first video. I had already had amniocentesis several weeks earlier, to check for chromosomal abnormalities associated with so-called elderly gravidas like my 38-year-old self.

headline.main: Ultrasound and Fury: One Mother's Ordeal

docs.abstract: Natalie Angier article questions routine use of ultrasound examination during pregnancy, noting possibility of false or misleading interpretations of scan; describes how ultrasound scan led her obstetrician to caution that her baby might be born with clubfoot, creating terrible anxiety for her and her husband; baby was born healthy and normal; photo (M)
